text: From far above it looks like a great clockwork. We are looking down on the Grand Hall of the Paris Train Station. It is crowded. People bustle back and forth. Like the gears and wheels of a clock. A precise, beautiful machine. We float down... Under the great iron girders... Moving through the station... Past kiosks and shops... Weaving among commuters... We stop at a clock set into the station wall. Behind the ironwork dial we see a face peering out. HUGO CABRET looks at us. He is a serious-looking boy of around 12. Long hair. It is 1931.

Hugo turns away from the dial and moves through the tunne behind the clock. A serpentine maze of passageways. Behind the walls. Hugo’s secret world. He moves quickly up and down spiral staircases ... duckin through tiny openings ... swerving in and out of dark passages ... up and down, back and forth... Like an elaborate game of Chutes and Ladders. He finally stops. Peers through another clock dial into a different part of the station.  He sees... A TOY BOOTH. Bedraggled and struggling. A counter filled with windup t dolls and little games. GEORGES, a grim old man with a white goatee, sits at the counter of the booth. Hugo watches. ISABELLE appears from inside the booth and talks to the o man. She has a book under her arm. She is a lively, imaginative girl about Hugo’s age. She h a charming Louise Brooks haircut. Isabelle argues a bit with Georges. He snaps at her. Upse she hurries off. Hugo watches her go. Then he turns his gaze to the toys on the counter. He sees the old man aimlessly wind a TOY MOUSE. It skitte across the counter. The old man crosses his arms. Falls asleep. Hugo stares at the toy mouse. Then he moves. He skitters through a series of passages and opens an air vent. He carefully climbs out, into the station...

Hugo creeps to the Toy Booth. The toy mouse is there on the counter. Georges still appears to be asleep. Hugo stops. Waits. Looks around. Carefully reaches for the toy mouse-- But--  Georges’ eyes snap open--! He grabs Hugo--! Hugo drops the toy mouse-- It falls and breaks-- Hugo struggles. Georges holds him firm.
Got you at last, my little thief. Quick, empty your pockets!
You’re hurting me!

Empty your pockets or I’1ll call the Station Inspector! Do as I say! The threat of the Station Inspector terrifies Hugo. He quickly empties his pockets. Dozens of objects. Screws Nails. Bits of metal and glass. Tiny pieces of clockworks Cogs and wheels.
And the other one.
There’s nothing in it!

(Starts to call) Where’s the Station Inspector...?! Hugo empties his last pocket. Reluctantly giving up a precious object: An old cardboard NOTEBOOK. Georges flips through it-- He sees words, pictures, engineering diagrams, schematics clockwork drawings-- Then he suddenly stops flipping-- Shocked-- It is like he has seen a ghost-- He stares at a page of the notebook--  4. A drawing of a MECHANICAL MAN man with clockwork innards. elegant and complex mechanism. But it is the face of the mechanical man that transfixes. Strangely passive and yet expressing a sort of sadness. O wisdom. It is a haunting face. Georges thumbs through a few pages of the notebook. It is like an old FLIPBOOK. The mechanical man’s face changes perspective as the page flip past. Like primitive animation. Georges stops. Slowly closes the notebook.
(whispers) Ghosts... He turns to Hugo. Sadness turning to rage.
Did you draw these pictures?! (no response) Did you draw these pictures?! Hugo tries to pull away. Georges’ grip is iron.
Where did you steal this?!
I didn’t steal it!
A thief and a liar. Georges releases Hugo.
Get out of my sight.
Give me my notebook!
It is no longer your notebook, it is my notebook and I'll do with it what I want. Maybe I’1l just burn it.
No!
Then tell me who did the drawings. Hugo glares at him. Says nothing. Georges suddenly SLAMS his fist down on the counter. All toys jump.

head_text.subj: GET OUT OF HERE, YOU LITTLE THIEF

text: His shout echoes around the station... Reverberating from walls ... ceiling ... girders ... wind +.. all around the cavernous station... To the ears of... MAXIMILIAN -- an enormous Doberman Pinscher. His ears perk up. His head tilts dangerously. He glares. Listening. Alert. THE STATION INSPECTOR, his master, glances down at him. The Station Inspector is a tall man in a bottle-green coa flamboyantly frightening ... Made even more menacing by a squeaking metal brace that bolts around one leg. He’s lik partly mechanical man. He and Maximilian are twin figures of implacable severity
Maximilian? ... What do you hear? -.-.- Do you hear ... malfeasance?! The dog growls dangerously. Strains at his leash. The Station Inspector smiles.

Go!  He releases the terrible hound-- Maximilian bolts-- The Station Inspector follows -- he is remarkably agile w his iron-shrouded leg, moving like an elegant spider-- Maximilian tears through the station-- People leap aside in shock and terror as the ferocious do sweeps past-- The Station Inspector spiders after him, his boots poundi over the polished floors, his leg brace squeaking wildly- Maximilian’s nails slips as he rounds a corner, he almost spins out, but doesn’t-- For ahead he sees-- Hugo. At the toy booth. Hugo sees the dog and sprints-- Running away in desperation-- Maximilian pursues-—

The chase is on! Huge weaves through pedestrians -- whips around corners - races down and up stairs -- leaping over luggage-- Maximilian on his heels-- The Station Inspector follows relentlessly-- Insane whirlwind momentum as the station zips past-- Hugo pants for air, glancing back in panic-- Maximilian is closer and closer-- The Station Inspector spiders after them -- his leg brace screeching -- his green coat flaring out behind him like bat’s wings-- Hugo speeds through a CAFE, agilely weaving between the little tables and the sniffy French waiters--  7. Maximilian follows, not quite so agilely, upsetting table and waiters-- Chaos--! MADAME EMILIE, the shy older woman who runs the cafe, scr and clutches her beloved little DACHSHUND to her chest-- The dachshund barks furiously at Maximilian-- Hugo loops around a table-- Where a man who looks suspiciously like James Joyce is ha a demitasse with a man who looks suspiciously like Salvad Dali-- They are agog as Hugo races around them ... followed by Maximilian ... followed by the Station Inspector-- Hugo finally sprints away from the cafe. Tearing through the crowded terminal again. The Station Inspector calls after him:

MONSIEUR FRICK, the shy older gentleman who runs a NEWSPA KIOSK across from the cafe, makes a half-hearted grab for Hugo-— But Hugo suddenly-- Dives-- Sliding on the polished floor between Monsieur Frick’s le Then he’s up and gone-- Monsieur Frick looks up, alarmed, leaps to the side as-- Maximilian thunders past-- The Station Inspector follows -- by now Hugo has disappea around a corner-- The Station Inspector and Maximilian rip around the corne top speed--

But Hugo is gone--!  8. And ahead -- a MATRONLY WOMAN and her two UNIFORMED VALET carrying towers of boxes from the most exclusive stores i Paris-- The Station Inspector and Maximilian try to stop -- but c -- momentum too great -- collision inevitable--

Boxes flying everywhere -- Valets knocked aside -- Matron Woman bellowing like Margaret Dumont -- the Station Inspe and Maximilian tangled! We move away from the chaos... Toward a wall... To find Hugo ... Safe behind an air vent ... Watching. He sees the Station Inspector pull himself up. Squeak his brace once in anger. Thwarted.
Hugo weaves through the tunnels. Comes to an iron door and enters...

It is like stepping into the heart of a mechanical toy. Wheels and gears hang everywhere. There are rows of jars filled with cogs, screws and bits of toys. Tools. Scaveng furniture. Hugo’s home and makeshift workshop. He sits on a battered old trunk for a moment. Disheartene He pulls out a large POCKET WATCH. Looks at it. Takes a deep breath. Time to go to work. He picks up a bucket of heavy tools and goes.

Huge moves through the tunnels.  9. Stops behind a large clock. He can see the station throug the clock face. He checks the time on his pocket watch. Then he uses tools from the bucket to wind the clock’s mechanism. Then he continues on. Opens a hatch and climbs down a rickety ladder...

He climbs down into a large clock that is suspended from ceiling of the Grand Hall. Clock dials and intricate work surround him on all four sides. While he winds all four clockworks, he looks out into the station below... He sees Madame Emilie, the shy older woman who runs the c cooing to her little dachshund. He sees Monsieur Frick, the shy older gentleman who runs newspaper kiosk, watching her. Monsieur Frick summons up his nerve. Timidly approaches h Bows rather formally. She is delighted. He tries to pet t dachshund. The dog snaps at him. Madame Emilie is mortifi Monsieur Frick retreats. Hugo climbs up, out of the clock...
Hugo continues on. Climbs a ladder to a narrow passage that overlooks a platform...

Hugo moves along a narrow passage above a station platfor He must kneel to wind this clock, which is at his foot le Through the clock he sees... MONSIEUR ROULEAU is a flamboyant young artist. He is pain at an easel. He is a Surrealist. His painting is wildly abstract.  10. Some SUBURBAN COMMUTERS stop to look. They ridicule the painting. Monsieur Rouleau tries to ignore them. Hugo feels bad for him. Hugo completes winding the clock and goes...
Hugo climbs and climbs and climbs. His bucket of tools is heavy. An endless staircase inside a high tower.

Hugo emerges at the very top of the station. An enormous clock. The motors and gears of the mechanism huge, bigger than he is. Hugo puts a crank into the works uses all his strength to turn it. It is like something out of METROPOLIS. And beyond the clock... Paris. A panoramic view. Somewhat unreal. Like an exquisite toy model. Exhausted, Hugo finally completes winding the clock. He takes a moment to look over the majestic city. And we fade to...
The Grand Hall is almost empty. Georges, in his hat and coat, is closing up the shop. Pul down a heavy grate. Hugo stands silently behind him.  11.
(not turning) I know you’re there ... What’s your name, boy?
Hugo ... Hugo Cabret.

Stay away from me, Hugo Cabret, or I’‘1l drag you to the Station Inspector's office and he’1ll lock you up in his little cell and you'll never get out and you’1ll never go to school and you'll never get married and have children of your own to take things that don’t belong to them. Georges completes locking the gate and goes. Hugo follows. They walk through the echoing station.
Give me back my notebook.

I am going home to burn your notebook. Georges sweeps through the doors, leaving the station. Hugo stops at the doors, hesitates for a moment. He is extremely uncomfortable at the idea of leaving the station. It has become his whole world. Everything beyond threatening. But his need now is great. He steels himself, takes a bre and pushes through the doors, following Georges.

Georges walks through the dark streets of Paris. Hugo follows. It is the spirit of the great city we see, not the real thing. Shapes and silhouettes of buildings. Architectural details. Sounds. Illusion.  12. Like a lovingly crafted 1930's movie set.
You can’t burn my notebook.

And who’s to stop me? Hugo wasn’t prepared for leaving the station. It’s cold. has no winter coat. He pulls his clothes tightly around h Later... Georges walks on. Hugo follows. A little closer. Later... Georges walks under a street lamp. Hugo follows. A little closer still. Later... Georges walks over a bridge. Hugo follows. A little closer still. Later... Georges moves through a sinister alley. Hugo, scared, is walking right next to him now. Georges ignores him. Snow begins to fall.
Georges and Hugo walk through a graveyard. Twisted trees. The shape of tombstones. Like Lean’s GREAT EXPECTATIONS. Snow continues to fall.

Georges walks to a decrepit apartment building. Right acr from the graveyard. Shabby part of town.  13. The old man stops and unlocks the chipped front door with large key. Hugo waits. Georges enters the building and, without a glance, slams door shut behind him. Hugo stands there. Snow falls. Hugo steps back, studies the building. He sees Georges enter an upper floor apartment. Sees a handsome older woman -- his wife -- greet him. They disap from view. Huge scans the other windows. He sees Isabelle, the girl the Toy Booth, in another room of the apartment. She is reading by the window. Hugo watches her. Snow collects on his head. He finally tosses a pebble up at the window. Isabelle loo down. Sees him. She stares at him quizzically. He motions for her to come down. She is intrigued but unsure. He motions. Begs. Please. Isabelle smiles. She loves nothing more than an adventure. She disappears from the window.
Hugo stands shivering. Isabelle runs to him.
Who are you?  14.
Your grandfather stole my notebook. I need to get it back before he burns it.
Papa Georges isn’t my grandfather and he isn’t a thief! He told me all about you, young gentleman. You’re nothing but a... a reprobate! She is delighted with the word. He doesn’t understand.
Can you help me get inside?
No. You have to go.
Not without my notebook--
Why do you need it so badly?
(hesitates) I... I can’t tell you.
Is it a secret?!
Yes.
Good! I love secrets! Tell me this instant!
No!
If you won’t tell me you have to go.
Not without--
I’‘1l get in trouble. Just go home! He won’t budge.
All right! I'11 make sure he doesn’t burn your notebook. He looks at her.
Trust me. He looks at her. He nods. He runs off. She watches him go. What a strange boy. She smiles.

Hugo enters. Still cold. He strikes a match. Lights a few candles. A golden glow fills the strange chamber. 15. Hugo takes out his pocket watch and hangs it on a special hook by the bed. Then he moves to a corner... There is something covered in an old sheet... He pulls off the sheet to reveal... The AUTOMATON. An amazing mechanical man. A couple feet tall. Exposed ge and levers. Clockworks and springs. In a state of disrepa We recognize the strange, haunting face from the drawings Hugo’s notebook. The Automaton sits at a little desk. Pen poised to write something. Hugo stares at the passive face of the Automaton. And remembers.  16.
What is it...?
It’s called an Automaton. The color fades as we go six months back in time...

The memory has the quality of a SILENT FILM. Black-and-wh Simple images. The flickering, glowing luminescence of ea movies. Hugo and his FATHER live in a poor, cramped garret. Big skylight. Paris beyond. An enormous full moon beyond that The Automaton -- now in much worse condition, battered an rusty, missing parts -- sits before Hugo and his Father.
An Automaton...
I found him abandoned in the attic of the museum.
What does he do?
(tinkering with it) He’s a windup figure, like a music box ... This is the most complicated one I’ve ever seen by far. You see? This one can write.
(transfixed) Who built him?
I would think a magician.
A magician!
That’s right. Magicians used machines like this when I was a boy. No one could figure out how they danced or walked or sang. (MORE )
But the secret was always in the clockwork.
Can we fix it?!
Oh, I don’t know, Hugo, it’s awfully rusted and finding the parts would be... He sees Hugo’s disappointment.

Of course we can fix it! We’re clock makers, aren’t we! ... But only when I’ve gotten through all my work at the shop and at the museum, you understand? Hugo hugs him. His father smiles. The Automaton seems to watch them.
Music. Hugo sweeps up as his father works fixing clocks. The tiny, cramped shop is a jumble of clocks, watches, ge movements, springs, dials.
Music. Hugo’s father winds and oils clocks in an old museum fill with Victorian curiosities.

Music. Hugo and his father work on the Automaton together. They huddle at the workbench. Hugo’s father patiently teaches him. Hugo learns eagerly. Hugo’s father stops to make a note.  18. We realize he is writing in the NOTEBOOK, the one Georges took.

Music. Hugo’s father is working on a stubborn clock at the museu Then... The music stops... Hugo’s father slowly turns... Curious... He moves to a stairway... Looks down... He sees... A PILLAR OF FLAME. Raging right up at him.
It is very late. Hugo is working on the Automaton. The door opens. He turns eagerly:
I fixed the gears in the-- But it is not his father. It is his UNCLE CLAUDE. Unshaven. Greasy. Crude. Huge.
Uncle Claude...?
There was a fire. Your father’s dead. Pack your things quickly. You’re coming with me.  19. Hugo stares.
Hugo lugs the heavy Automaton, covered in a sheet, as he follows Uncle Claude through the empty streets. Hugo struggles to keep up with Uncle Claude’s huge gait.

You’1l be my apprentice. You'll live with me and I’1l show you how to take care of them clocks. (Takes a swig from a flask) I’m getting too old to be climbing through them tunnels. They turn a corner. And ahead of them... The Train Station.
Uncle Claude and Hugo enter the secret apartment. It is filthy and rank. Dickensian. Hugo sets down the Automaton. Looks around.
They built these apartments for them who ran the station, years ago. Everyone’s forgotten they’re here. You sleep in the corner. Uncle Claude plops down. Drinks.
Get some sleep. We start work at five.
What about school?

You're finished with school. There won't be time for that once you're in them walls ... You should thank me.  20. Uncle Claude clears his throat. Takes a drink. Looks away Hugo carries the Automaton to his corner. He sits. Dazed. Absolutely forlorn. Then he pulls the sheet off the Automaton. He looks into the Automaton’s face. His only friend. They sit together.
Funeral tableau. Hugo and Uncle Claude at the grave site. Uncle Claude dri from his flask. Hugo bows his head. Tears beginning to fall. Color gradually returns as we leave the past and return t
Hugo sits, looking at the Automaton. Alone. Despondent. We fade to...

Hugo peers out from behind an air vent. Waiting. Watching. Madame Emilie is opening her little cafe. Her dachshund hovers protectively. Monsieur Frick approaches cautiously. Bows gallantly and offers her a newspaper from his kiosk. Madame Emilie is charmed. The dachshund attacks this time! It chases Monsi Frick away. Madame Emilie follows in horror.  21. Hugo seizes his opportunity-- He scrambles quickly from the air vent-- Races to the cafe-- Grabs a croissant and bottle of milk-- Runs off-- Disappearing into the crowd of morning commuters. INT. TRAIN STATION -- GRAND HALL —- MORNING Hugo moves through the grown up world, eating the croissa No one notices him. He sees the imposing Station Inspector and the ferocious Maximilian approaching! Hugo moves next to a woman. Falls into step. Acts like he son. She doesn’t notice. The Station Inspector passes. Hugo continues on. But Maximilian stops. Turns. Sniffs.
What is it? He looks. Sees nothing.
We shall be alert, my friend ... We shall be ... vigilant. He and Maximilian go.
Georges is opening the Toy Booth. Hugo stands silently behind him.
I thought I might see you today.
I need my notebook.  22.
Why do you need it so badly?
To help me ... fix something.

What? Hugo doesn’t answer. Georges hands Hugo a handkerchief tied up into a bundle. unties it. Ashes. It is filled with ashes. Burned paper. Hugo looks at the ashes. Horror and disbelief. Tears stin his eyes. He can’t breathe. The ashes fall... Cascade and swirl delicately down... Over Hugo’s shoes... To the floor. Hugo looks up at Georges. He is shocked to see there are tears in Georges’ eyes as well.

Go away ... Please just go away. Hugo wipes his eyes with his dirty, ashen hands, leaving black smudges on his face. He backs away. Then he turns and runs off. Tears flowing freely now. He races around a corner and--
--Bang! He runs right into Isabelle. She was hiding, waiting for  23.
Hey!
Sorry -- I--
I saw. Are you crying?
No!
Hold still. She uses her handkerchief to dry his eyes and clean his f as:
There’s nothing wrong with crying. Sidney Carton cries. And Heathcliff too. In books they’re crying all the time.
(grabs handkerchief) I can do it!

I have to talk to you. It’s terribly important. But not here. We’re too ... exposed. She dramatically grabs his hand and pulls him off. INT. TRAIN STATION -- GRAND HALL —- MORNING Hugo continues to clean his face as they move through a different part of the station. She is carrying a book.
Where are we going?
Only to the most wonderful place on earth! Neverland and Oz and Treasure Island all wrapped up into one. They are approaching Monsieur Rouleau. He is at work on h Surrealist painting.  24.
Good morning, Monsieur Rouleau.
Morning. She stops and looks at the abstract painting.
Oh, it’s coming along marvelously!
What is it?
It’s the station ... How I see it anyway ... Do you like it? Hugo looks at the painting. Takes it seriously. Isabelle appreciates this.
You know, I think I do ... Yes, I like it very much. Monsieur Rouleau is pleased.
We have to go ... Well done, Monsieur Rouleau! Hugo and Isabelle go.
He’s a Surrealist.
Mm.
That’s a kind of painter.
I know what a Surrealist is. I’m not an idiot.
Ah, here we are! Ahead of them... Her secret realm ... Wonderland and Oz and Treasure Islan all wrapped up into one...  25. A used bookstore. They enter.

A little bell jangles when they enter. MONSIEUR LABISSE, the shop owner, is perched high on a st at the front of the store like the Caterpillar from ALICE WONDERLAND, peering over a stack of dusty books. He is a slight, sad sort of man. He brightens when he see Isabelle. But he is extremely suspicious of Hugo.
Good morning, Monsieur Labisse, may I present Monsieur Hugo Cabret, a very old and dear boon companion.
(bows ) Monsieur Cabret.
Hello.
(handing him book) Thank you for this. I think I’m halfway in love with David Copperfield ... Photography?
(points) Back corner left, top shelf.

Thank you. Monsieur Labisse watches them go. Hugo’s dirty clothes an long hair convince him he must be a shoplifter -- or wors Isabelle leads Hugo deeper into the store. It is a world of books. Stacked in every direction. To th ceiling. Rivers of books. Mountains of books. Gloriously cluttered.
Listen, what’s so important?  26.
Papa Georges still has your notebook. He didn’t burn it. That was all a trick.
Why? She climbs a ladder in search of a book:
I don’t know. The notebook made him very upset. He and Mama Jeanne stayed up late talking about it. I think he was crying. Hugo thinks about this. How strange.
It’s a mystery.
I know!
Why are you helping me?
Because this might be an adventure! I’ve never had one, outside of books. She grabs a book. Comes back down the ladder.
I think we should be very ... clandestine.
Okay.
By the way, my name’s Isabelle ... Do you want a book? Monsieur Labisse lets me borrow them. I could get one for you.
No.
(horrified) Don’t you like books?!  27.
No, I do ... My father and I used to read Jules Verne together... He stops. She senses his strong emotion. Respects it. They move to Monsieur Labisse at the front counter.
(xe: book) May I?
Of course. Good day, Isabelle. Monsieur Labisse watches Hugo with suspicion as they leav the shop.
They move through the bustling station.
How do I get my notebook back?

I think you should stand up to him. He'll respect that ... Don’t tell him we talked. I’1l help you if I can ... Be steadfast! She disappears into the crowd. He watches her go. Be steadfast? What a peculiar girl.

Georges is sitting at the counter. Evenly staring at something. He aimlessly cuts and re-cuts a deck of cards with one ha as he stares. We finally see what he is staring at... Hugo stands there on the other side of the counter. Stari back at him. Steadfast.  It is like a showdown. Finally:
I don’t believe you burned my notebook.
You don’t? ... Well, maybe I did and maybe I didn’t. You’1l never know, will you? Hugo holds his ground.
Shall I call the Station Inspector? Hugo holds his ground.

Go ... away. Hugo holds his ground. Georges glares at him. Hugo glares back. A long beat. Gunfighters. Neither blinks. Then... Georges slowly reaches under the counter... He pulls something out... Something covered in a handkerchief... He sets it on the counter... 28. With the panache of a magician, he pulls off the handkerc to reveal... The toy mouse that Hugo broke earlier.
Fix it. Hugo looks at him.  29.
I said, fix it.
I need my tools. Georges pulls out a canister of tiny screwdrivers, pliers files and hammers.
I know you’ve been stealing parts from the shop ... Might as well use those you haven’t stolen yet. Hugo looks at the broken toy mouse. Then at Georges.
If I fix it, do I get my notebook?

We'll see. A challenge. Hugo starts to work. He uses the tiny tools ... hammering ... screwing ... adjusting ... tinkering... Georges watches. Hugo fixes the spring ... fits the key ... hammers the body... Finally he sets the toy mouse down on the counter. Georges looks at it. He winds it. The toy mouse skitters playfully across the counter. Georges is impressed, tries not to show it.
Give me my notebook.
You've got a bit of talent. But you'll have to prove there’s more to you than being a thief ... You can earn your notebook.
How?
Come to the booth everyday. I'll decide how long you must work for each item you stole, and it will be up to me to decide when you have earned your notebook, if ever.
I already have a job.
Thief is not a job, boy.
I have another job, but I’1l come when I can.
You begin tomorrow. Go away.

I’1l begin now. Hugo bravely goes into the booth and gets a broom. Starts sweeping up. Georges watches him. 30. Across the station, a little DANCE BAND is starting up at Madame Emilie’s cafe. A few couples dance. An afternoon tea dance. A lovely, bygone image. Couples dancing under the massive iron ribs of the great train station. The music echoes throughout the Grand Hall. The music from the band takes us to...

Dance band music as... --. Hugo works at the Toy Booth. Across the booth, does a card trick. Hugo watches the trick closely. notices. Georges Georges  31. .-. Isabelle and Hugo walk through the bookstore, chattin Monsieur Labisse eyes Hugo with suspicion. -.. Georges teaches Hugo how to do the card trick. .-. Hugo demonstrates the card trick to the Automaton. ... Hugo repairs a broken toy in the booth. Isabelle is there, chatting to him. He ducks away when the Station Inspector and Maximilian pass. She is intrigued. -.. Georges watches Hugo demonstrate the card trick to a customer. He hides a smile. .-. Hugo works on the Automaton. It looks done: polished, cleaned, beautiful and ready. But for one thing. We now s that there is HEART-SHAPED KEYHOLE in the back. --. Hugo tries a bit of bent metal in the keyhole. Doesn’ fit. He adds it to a collection of scavenged items he has tried. Nothing fits. .--. Isabelle and Hugo playfully dance to the band at the with other couples. -.. Georges watches them dance. Content. ... The band dance ends the song with a flourish. Hugo bo to Isabelle. She laughs. The montage ends.

Hugo is waiting for Isabelle outside the book shop. He sees the Station Inspector and Maximilian cutting thro the crowd. Hugo ducks around a corner and watches nervous But the Station Inspector has another quarry today. A young STREET KID, around Hugo’s age, is loitering near another shop. The Station Inspector stalks him and then sweeps down lik bird of prey. The Street Kid makes a move to bolt-- But the Station Inspector releases Maximilian, who leaps, crouches and snarls in front of the terrified Kid-- The Station Inspector grabs the Kid brutally. Shakes him.  32.
Where are you parents?! Answer me!

(terrified) Got none. Without another word, the Station Inspector drags him awa his leg brace squeaking ominously. Maximilian loping afte them. Hugo darts into an air vent. INT. TRAIN STATION -- NARROW PASSAGE/INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - Hugo is in a cramped passage that overlooks the Station Inspector's office, peering through a clock face. The Street Kid is in a tiny, awful cell. He is sobbing. Maximilian sits alert, glaring in at the Kid. The Station Inspector is oiling his leg brace as he talks the phone:
(on phone) +». yes, another one. Useless waste of an orphan by the looks of it. Come get it. Suddenly-- Maximilian turns. Looks toward Hugo, ears perked. Hugo sinks back into the darkness.

Hugo watches through a clock face. He sees the Station Inspector dragging the Street Kid thr the doors of the station and throwing him into a police truck. The truck roars off. The Station Inspector comes back inside. He stands looking over his domain. Maximilian at his side Imperious. Hugo disappears back into the tunnels.  33. We linger for a moment with the Station Inspector. His ey scan the terminal. Then he stops. He watches LISETTE. A beautiful and shy girl who runs a little flower stall. She’s organizing bunches of flowers. They surround her: an explosion of vibrant color in the terminal. The Station Inspector gazes at her. He’s besotted, has be for a while. He gets up his nerve ... Puts on an awkward smile ... He begins to approach... But then his leg brace squeaks sharply. It echoes through terminal. He stops. Embarrassed. He gives up. Moves off with Maximilian.
Hugo and Isabelle move through the bookstore.
++. I’m still looking for your notebook. I have to be very circumspect. She loves the word.
You better not look inside.
If I find it I should be able to look inside it.
Then don’t look for it!
I’m trying to help. Why are you being so mean? His heart sinks.
Just ... Promise me you won’t open it.

Fine. To Hugo she suddenly looks very grown up. She is disappoi  34. They wander deeper into the store. Monsieur Labisse, perched on his high stool, keeps an war eye on Hugo. Hugo picks up a copy of ROBIN HOOD, smiles.
I saw this movie! With Douglas Fairbanks. Did you see that?
I’ve never seen a movie.
What?!
Isn’t it appalling?!
You’ve never seen a movie? Not ever?
Papa Georges won’t let me. He’s very strict about it.

(excited) I love movies! My father always took me for my birthday. Hugo is surprised he suddenly spoke about his father. He not regret it though. They wander through the teetering piles of books in silen
Is your father dead?
I don’t want to talk about it. A beat. She takes his hand for a quick moment, then releases it. A gesture of support. Friendship. They continue strolling. Hugo stops. An idea. He looks at her.  35.
Isabelle ... Do you want to have an adventure? Her eyes light up.
